Problem:
Let us consider a control system governed by the differential equation \( \dot{x} = Ax + Bu \), where \( A \) and \( B \) are constant matrices and \( u(t) \) represents a control input vector. The Laplace transform \( X(s) = \mathcal{L}\{x(t)\} \) applied to this system results in \( X(s) = (sI - A)^{-1}BU(s) + (sI - A)^{-1}x(0) \) where \( U(s) \) is the Laplace transform of \( u(t) \).

Assuming the control input \( u(t) \) is a constant vector \( u_0 \) from \( t = 0 \), with no further changes, will the Laplace transform of \( x(t) \) at any \( s \) differ if \( u(t) \) had been a different constant \( \tilde{u}_0 \)?
Explanation: The constant control inputs \( u_0 \) and \( \tilde{u}_0 \) result in different Laplace transforms due to their impact in the term \( (sI - A)^{-1}BU(s) \). Since \( U(s) \) and hence \( X(s) \) directly depend on the value of the control input \( U(s) = \frac{U_0}{s} \), where \( U_0 \) is the Laplace transform of \( u_0 \), different control inputs lead to different system responses in the Laplace domain.
